title: Why unpretentious Andalucia is my favourite destination for food – and three dishes that sum up the region
text:
Raw, rugged limestone escarpments, plunging ravines, snail-like roads curling through wild sierra, herds of goats with tinkling bells, vineyards and bodegas, wooded meadows dotted with snuffling black pigs, hillsides striped with regimented rows of olive-trees, whitewashed fincas, villages sprinkled with potted geraniums and – nearly always – a hulking Moorish castle or lone watchtower peering down from above; these are some of the varied characteristics of rural Andalucia.

As most tourism clings to the Mediterranean coast or to the big three cities of Seville, Granada and Cordoba, Andalucia’s interior is blissfully deserted, leaving the dizzying bends to those in search of the authentic. This is where village tapas bars still serve free morsels with your caña (beer), fountains gush with spring water and, during the autumn olive harvest, a frenzy of activity takes over from the deep summer slumber.
